awd_titl_txt: Career And Research Exploration to Enhance Retention in STEM (CAREERS)
awd_abstract_narration:
In many situations, the main reason why students do not persist in STEM fields is the lack of knowledge about the comprehensive range of STEM careers available to them once they graduate.  Buena Vista University's multi-disciplinary Career And Research Exploration to Enhance Retention in STEM (CAREERS) program leverages career knowledge in STEM as a novel tool for increased retention of low income, minority, rural (LIMR) undergraduate students in STEM. The project targets STEM majors in biology, biochemistry, chemistry, computer science, environmental science, mathematics, physics and science education. With support from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, CAREERS will provide scholarships and strategic student support to cohorts of Pell-eligible, academically talented students. 

Evidence suggests that not only do underrepresented minority students have reduced access to role models and mentors but they also experience lower expectations from faculty and lack strong social support networks, all necessary elements for college success. This CAREERS project provides a spectrum of effective interventions such as learning communities, tutoring, mentoring, success programs, and a robust career development plan to enhance underrepresented students' success and retention in STEM fields. Specific activities include seminar-style courses, a career-focused science sampler trip, capstone experiences, directed exploration of science as applied to industry, interdisciplinary research opportunities, internships, and outreach presentations. These will provide critical ingredients for successful STEM career exploration and selection. The project will add to the research literature on ways in which targeted recruitment strategies integrated with curricular, co-curricular, and extracurricular programming around STEM careers shape the career trajectories of LIMR students. CAREERS can potentially provide a model for STEM programs across the country, especially at liberal arts colleges that tend to enroll a high number of students underrepresented in STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
The Career and Research Exploration to Enhance Retention in STEM (CAREERS) Program at Buena Vista University had the following objectives:

 Project objectives

1. To attract underrepresented students to Buena Vista University’s STEM program

2. To increase enrollment in STEM majors

3. To foster student success and persistence to graduation with a rigorous and thorough experience grounded in broad, multi-disciplinary perspectives on STEM careers by creating a unique and focused network of student and career supports

4. To increase graduation from STEM majors

5. To continue to offer the program beyond the funding of NSF to recruit, retain and graduate underrepresented, low-income students into Buena Vista’s STEM programs

 

The CAREERS recruitment strategies successfully increased enrollment of underrepresented students to BVU’s STEM program. While the overall rate of ethnic minority students has remained relatively stable since the 2015-16 baseline, increases since 2019 have been seen. The rates of rural students increased with the arrival of the 2018 and 2019 cohorts from a baseline of 49 first year students in 2015-16 to 55 enrolling in 2018-19 and 66 enrolling in 2019-20; which include students enrolled in the CAREERS program. Rates have remained between 60% and 70% for the years past the CAREERS program enrollment.  An increased trend is also found regarding low-income students as defined by Pell eligible; the 2015-16 baseline of low-income first year students was 22 and the number in 2018-19 was 25 and in 2019-20 was 41. All students enrolled in the CAREERS program are considered low-income students.  The rates of women enrolling as first-years in STEM programs remained in the 20s from 2015-16 baseline through the 2018 start of the program, but the numbers have risen to 35 in 2019-20 and 2020-21 and 37 in 2021-2022.  Improvements on recruitment strategies have risen since the program enrollment ended by creating dedicated high-impact experiences such as dissections and robotics and career information and embedding them into recruitment days offered by STEM programs. This year, 41 HS students participated in a specialized mathematics visit day, 95 in computer science, and 62 in health sciences. To date, 36% of high school participants have registered at BVU.

 

The increased student support and programming in career exploration and development as well as multi-level mentoring program developed for the CAREERS program has led to increased student success and persistence to graduation. Persistence in STEM was measured for several demographics.  It is defined here as the percentage of students that graduated from BVU with STEM majors who began as STEM majors at BVU. Out of 33 students enrolled in the CAREERS program across the two cohorts, 26 graduated from or are still enrolled in STEM majors at BVU (78.79% of students enrolled) with a 3.55 average GPA. Institutional data on the 2019-20 class is not yet determined, but baseline data prior to and including the 2018-2019 class shows graduation rates in STEM fields with a 36.5% three-year average.  Twenty out of 24 (83.3%) CAREERS students that were Pell eligible persisted in STEM with institutional persistence at 31.1%. All 6 ethnic minorities in the CAREERS program persisted in STEM compared to institutional persistence at 17.5%. Sixteen out of 22 (72.7%) of CAREERS students from rural communities persisted in STEM compared to 39.8% for BVU. Fifteen out of 19 (78.9%) women in CAREERS persisted compared to 42.2% for BVU persistence in STEM. Enhancements made to academic and student support programs through the CAREERS program were reported by students as beneficial for their success academically and in obtaining internships and jobs.  

 

Several outcomes from the grant have been built on or utilized after the grant period. Already noted, enhanced recruitment strategies have been employed and career exploration and development are being embedded into several majors.  As a result of this grant, BVU will be investigating some new initiatives surrounding several of the grant outcomes that would embed mentorship and career and leadership development into programming to help recruit, retain, and train students for careers in STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 07/06/2023
Modified by: Lisa Mellmann
